title: Brussels-North railway station
text:
Brussels-North railway station (, ), officially Brussels-North (, ), is one of the three major <a href="railway%20station">railway station</a>s in <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a> (<a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>); the other two are <a href="Brussels%20Central%20Station">Brussels-Central</a> and <a href="Brussels-South%20railway%20station">Brussels-South</a>. Every regular domestic and international train (except <a href="Thalys">Thalys</a> and <a href="Eurostar">Eurostar</a>) passing there has a planned stop. The station has 200,000 passengers per week, mainly <a href="commuter">commuter</a>s, making it one of the <a href="List%20of%20railway%20stations%20in%20Belgium">busiest in Belgium</a>.
Brussels-North is the end point of the <a href="Brussels%20premetro">"premetro"</a> (underground tram) <a href="North%E2%80%93South%20Axis">North–South Axis</a> (on lines <a href="Brussels%20tram%20route%203">3</a> and <a href="Brussels%20tram%20route%204">4</a>), and an important node of the Brussels Intercommunal Transport Company (<a href="Brussels%20Intercommunal%20Transport%20Company">STIB/MIVB</a>), as well as of bus lines of the Flemish transport company <a href="De%20Lijn">De Lijn</a>. More than 30 regional bus lines depart from there, as do international <a href="Eurolines">Eurolines</a> coach services.
The station is located in the <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a> municipality of <a href="Schaerbeek">Schaerbeek</a>, in the middle of the <a href="Northern%20Quarter%2C%20Brussels">Northern Quarter</a> <a href="central%20business%20district">business district</a> (also called "Little Manhattan"), with several corporation headquarters such as <a href="Belgacom%20Towers">Belgacom Towers</a>, <a href="Rogier%20Tower">Rogier Tower</a> and others, government offices, as well as Flemish ministries. Right next to the station is the <a href="Rue%20d%27Aerschot">Rue d'Aerschot/Aarschotstraat</a>, an area of prostitution "behind windows".
Naming.
The Brussels-Capital Region is <a href="Multilingualism">bilingual</a>; hence, both the French and Dutch names of the station— and —are official. Outside Belgium, this often leads to the use of combined shorthands; for example in the "<a href="Thomas%20Cook%20European%20Rail%20Timetable">Thomas Cook European Rail Timetable</a>", Brussels-North is designated as " /"; <a href="Nederlandse%20Spoorwegen">NS</a> (Dutch Railways) announce the station as "Brussel Noord/Nord". The station's bilingual French–Dutch name is otherwise generally translated in English to "Brussels-North". 
History.
First and second stations (1835–1952).
The very first railway station in Brussels was / railway station near the site of today's <a href="Yser%20metro%20station">Yser/IJzer metro station</a>. It was from there that, on 5 May 1835, the first passenger train on a public railway in <a href="continental%20Europe">continental Europe</a> departed. This first station was replaced in March 1846 by a new monumental station on the <a href="Place%20Charles%20Rogier">Place Charles Rogier/Karel Rogierplein</a>, a short distance east from the original site, on the territory of the municipality of <a href="Saint-Josse-ten-Noode">Saint-Josse-ten-Noode</a>. Designed by the architect François Coppens in <a href="Neoclassical%20architecture%20in%20Belgium">neoclassical</a> style, this second "North Station" (, ) was a single-storey railway complex that stretched in width from the <a href="Rue%20d%27Aerschot">Rue d'Aerschot/Aarschotstraat</a> to the /, and in length, from the Place Rogier to the / (nowadays a tunnel). To connect the neighbourhoods on both sides of the railway, there were only two pedestrian bridges: one at Rogier Square and the other at the /. It consisted of 27 tracks.
The Belgian railway network grew rapidly during the second half of the 19th century, becoming the densest on the continent. By then, Brussels-North and <a href="Brussels-South%20railway%20station">Brussels-South</a> had become the primary railway stations in Brussels. However, they were joined only by an inadequate single track running along what is today the route of <a href="Small%20Ring%2C%20Brussels">Brussels' inner ring road</a>. Many proposals were put forward to link the two stations more substantially. A law was finally passed in 1909 mandating a <a href="North%E2%80%93South%20connection">direct connection</a>; however, the final project would not be completed until more than a century later.
Current station (1952–present).
In 1952, a new transit station, located a few hundred metres further north, was built. It was designed in post-war <a href="Modernist%20architecture">modernist</a> style by architects Jacques and Paul Saintenoy, assisted by Jean Hendrickx Vanden Bosch. The construction of the <a href="North%E2%80%93South%20connection">North–South connection</a> between 1910 and 1953 ensured a train connection between the new station and the <a href="Brussels-South%20railway%20station">South Station</a>. During the construction of the North–South connection, the tracks were raised and several underpasses were added. The old station on the Place Rogier was razed in 1955. A bus station was built on its former site, and then in 1960, the Rogier International Centre (, ), also called the Martini Tower, which was formerly the tallest building in Belgium, and which housed the National Theatre of Belgium until 1999. The building was demolished in 2001, and was replaced by the <a href="Rogier%20Tower">Rogier Tower</a>. A group of statues from the station's former facade were reconstructed at the Warandepark in <a href="Diest">Diest</a>, <a href="Flemish%20Brabant">Flemish Brabant</a>, Belgium.
An extensive public transport complex, the so-called North Communication Center (or CCN) was built on the western side of the North Station in the 1970s. As a result, the station building (on the side of the /) is now part of this larger complex. The CCN connects the bus stop of <a href="De%20Lijn">De Lijn</a> and <a href="Brussels%20Intercommunal%20Transport%20Company">STIB/MIVB</a>, as well as the <a href="Brussels%20premetro">"premetro"</a>, with the railway station. In 1992, the Brussels-Capital Region decided to erect an <a href="Art%20Deco">Art Deco</a>-inspired office building for its officials above the CCN. Due to the construction of this CCN and the large volume of the office building above it, the architectural appearance of the North Station with its iconic clock tower was diminished.
Renovation works started in May 2010. The ticket hall was the first to be renovated and completed in 2012. The renovation works have been systematically continued since then. The intention is, among other things, to install new escalators and <a href="elevator">lift</a>s and for the Rue d'Aerschot to have a fully-fledged entrance. Unlike the South Station, which was largely remodelled for the arrival of international express trains, the North Station has kept most of its post-war materials and decorative elements, highlighted during this recent renovation. The station has also kept its original <a href="clock%20tower">clock tower</a>.
